item.title: ex-mistress says bonds blamed steroids for injury

item.title: rock hall inducts neil diamond, alice cooper
item.description: singer and songwriter neil diamond was inducted into the rock and roll hall of fame on monday, crooning his signature mellow rock songs in a stark contrast to fellow inductee heavy metal band alice cooper.

item.title: chicago news cooperative: among blacks, mayoral election forces a push for new ideas and leaders
item.description: the poor showing of carol moseley braun in the chicago mayoral election has galvanized many blacks to push for new ideas and new leaders in the black community.

item.description: a team led by chad hurley and steve chen, the co-founders of youtube, will buy the social bookmarking service.

item.description: nascar's most popular driver has some suggestions for improving exhibition race

item.title: czech village in cedar rapids struggles for a comeback
item.description: czech village seems determined to restore a connection with a country few of its residents have visited, a language that fewer speak, and a culture that has grown increasingly foreign.

item.description: nasa showed off some of the first pictures taken by its mercury messenger spacecraft.

item.description: a damaged egyptian pipeline that supplies natural gas to israel has been repaired, but the gas is not flowing so foreign shareholders are threatening legal action.

item.description: fewer kids in trouble are being sent to adult court because of states changing laws to keep young offenders away from adult prison.

item.description: braves third baseman chipper jones is expected to miss at least two more days with a small meniscus tear in his right knee.

item.title: rangers' callahan out indefinitely with broken ankle
item.description: the new york rangers' late-season push to clinch a playoff spot was dealt a blow as forward ryan callahan is out indefinitely with a broken ankle, the team said on tuesday.

item.title: more oppose than support republican medicare plan: poll
item.description: more americans oppose than support a republican plan to revamp the medicare healthcare program for seniors, presenting a challenge to the party ahead of next year's presidential and congressional elections.

item.title: citi says hackers access bank card data
item.description: citigroup inc said computer hackers breached the bank's network and accessed the data of about 200,000 bank card holders in north america, the latest of a string of cyber attacks on high-profile companies.

item.title: e.c.b. signals interest rate increase in july
item.description: the european central bank and the bank of england both held rates steady, but the e.c.b. president said "strong vigilance" against inflation was warranted.

item.title: bieber, angry birds among webby awards nominees
item.description: pop sensation justin bieber, grammy award winner arcade fire and the angry birds mobile game are among the nominees for the webby awards, the leading international honor for web content.

item.title: listen up: valleyheart, foster the people
item.description: impassioned and danceable songs of love and lust, and post-punk tunes to get you through the night.

item.title: on basketball: aggies coach has another story to tell
item.description: the arc of gary blair's career is the arc of women's basketball, from grudging tolerance to defiant outsider resolve to belated acceptance.

item.title: southwest: arizona: governor will appeal to supreme court
item.description: gov. jan brewer, a republican, said on monday that she would petition the u.s. supreme court to lift an injunction blocking some portions of arizona's controversial immigration law.

item.title: brazil inflation slows, analysts see more ahead
item.description: inflation in brazil slowed in the month to mid-march, possibly signaling a welcome respite in price pressures ahead even as annual inflation edged close to a government ceiling.

item.title: number of violent deaths rises in iraq in march
item.description: the number of civilians, police and soldiers killed in violence in iraq rose in march, official figures showed on friday, just days after militants killed 58 people in the month's deadliest attack.

item.description: the hangover, part ii tied one on this weekend, driving movie ticket sales to a memorial day record.

item.description: american nick watney kept his cool to win the wgc-cadillac championship on sunday by two strokes over compatriot dustin johnson for the biggest win of his career.

item.description: vancouver must return to nashville to try to close out the series in six games.

item.description: azerbaijan won the annual eurovision song contest with the romantic ballad "running scared" on saturday, watched by a television audience of more than 100 million people.

item.description: azerbaijan won the 2011 eurovision song contest saturday, taking top honors with a love song in the annual competition of 43 countries that was watched by an audience of more than 100 million people.

item.description: tim wakefield is a rare breed in major league baseball and the boston red sox knuckleballer will set a new milestone the next time he takes to the mound by becoming the oldest player ever to play for the team.

item.title: one dead, one injured in arizona desert shooting
item.description: one man was shot dead and a second wounded after a group of illegal entrants from mexico came under fire from suspected bandits in desert south of phoenix, authorities said on thursday.

item.title: eurovision head says global contest a "challenge"
item.description: the eurovision song contest has become so popular around the globe that there may be scope one day for a worldvision song contest, executive supervisor jon ola sand told reuters.

item.title: plains: hundreds in the dakotas flee the missouri river
item.description: hundreds of people in north and south dakota evacuated areas along the missouri river on friday as federal officials increased water releases to relieve pressure on six reservoirs.

item.description: the author talks to 's bob minzesheimer about five of the 25 most influential books.

item.description: airbus is under formal investigation for the crash in 2009 that killed 228 people aboard a flight to paris.

item.title: egypt orders "pharaoh" mubarak's name stripped off
item.description: egypt thursday took another step toward erasing the legacy of deposed president hosni mubarak by ordering his name, and that of his family, removed from public institutions across the nation.

item.description: the arrest of several journalists this month has prompted criticism of the government, both at home and abroad.

item.description: grafting a thigh muscle into the cheek of kids whose face has been paralyzed by brain surgery can help them smile again, new research shows.

item.description: an fa-18 fighter jet crashed on wednesday near a u.s. naval air station in central california, base officials said.

item.description: the broadway musical will close and move to new world stages.

item.title: children should ride in rear-facing car seats until age 2
item.description: new advice from the nation's pediatricians doubles the recommended time that babies and toddlers should ride in rear-facing car seats.

item.title: mets 4, rockies 3: davis helps mets win, but is injured in a collision
item.description: first baseman ike davis, who leads the team in home runs and runs batted in, left in the fifth inning with a strained left calf and is listed as day to day.

item.title: frictions seen easing in troubled u.n. rights body
item.description: the united states and ngo campaign groups wednesday said diplomatic shifts on highly- charged issues like religion and iran in the long-polarized u.n. human rights council could turn it into a more effective body.

item.title: canadian woman dies when swept over niagara falls
item.description: a canadian woman died when she was swept over niagara falls in what witness accounts indicate may have been a suicide, authorities said.

item.description: d. j. kennedy?s injury, along with the free falls that villanova and georgetown are experiencing, represent the other side of life in the grueling big east.

item.description: the tampa bay lightning finished a rebuilding season just one game short of a spot in the stanley cup finals, leaving first-year head coach guy boucher with a bitter-sweet feeling.

item.title: asset managers set to report higher profits
item.description: u.s. asset managers are expected to report higher profits for the march quarter after investors looking to take more risk poured money into stock and bond funds.

item.title: investors learn the hard way precious metals can be risky
item.description: there's a growing danger that investors are wading into commodity investing with incorrect expectations fanned by common misconceptions.

item.title: visa to launch digital wallet for u.s. banks
item.description: visa inc, the world's largest credit and debit card processing network, is building a digital wallet that people can use to pay for things online or with their phones instead of with traditional cards.

item.description: there is a proud mother who lives in texas. her son, todd pletcher, is the trainer of the winner of the 136th kentucky derby winner, super saver.

item.title: red sox yanked down again in horror start

item.description: the little guy wearing the sky blue and white striped jersey of argentina will be the center of attention in an international friendly match against the united states at new meadowlands stadium on saturday night.

item.title: middle east: libya: qatar deports dissident woman
item.description: the libyan woman whose mistreatment by the government of col. muammar el-qaddafi made her a symbol of its brutality has been deported against her will to benghazi.

item.title: after bin laden death, obama visits ground zero
item.description: days after the killing of osama bin laden, president barack obama met new york firefighters and police on thursday and visited ground zero to offer comfort to a city still scarred by the september 11 attacks.

item.title: heidi klum to go nude for 'runway' ad campaign
item.description: project runway is all about the clothes, but host heidi klum is taking hers off to promote the new season.

item.title: triple stanley cup winner rafalski retires at 37
item.description: three-times stanley cup champion brian rafalski has retired after 11 seasons in the nhl, the detroit red wings said on wednesday.

item.description: a u.s. citizen is being held in north korea and should be released on humanitarian grounds, the state department said on tuesday.

item.description: brian boucher stopped 35 shots as the flyers' new starting goalie to help philadelphia grab a first-round playoff series lead with a 4-2 win over the host buffalo sabres on monday.

item.title: apple sues samsung, says stop copying us
item.description: apple inc sued samsung electronics claiming the south korean firm's galaxy line of mobile phones and tablets "slavishly" copies the iphone and ipad, according to court papers, a move analysts say is aimed at keeping its close rivals at bay.

item.title: lawyer: iran postpones spy trial for 3 americans
item.description: the iranian lawyer for three americans charged with espionage says judicial authorities have not resumed their trial as planned.

item.title: no football? no problem for oakland
item.description: some cities are worried that the national football league lockout will turn into a canceled season, but oakland may actually save money if their team doesn't play.

item.description: picking a derby winner can sometimes seem as hard as training one.

item.title: auburn tree poisoning suspect goes on radio show
item.description: the alabama fan accused of poisoning his rival school's trees said on a birmingham radio show that he is going to get what he deserves and that he just has 'too much 'bama in me.'

item.title: texas house passes bill banning tsa airport "groping"
item.description: the texas house of representatives late on thursday approved a bill that would make invasive pat-downs at texas airports a crime, after a former miss usa said she felt "molested" at the dallas/fort worth airport last month.

item.title: nadal equals borg's record with sixth french open title
item.description: rafael nadal reeled in bjorn borg and won his sixth french open title by holding off his customary foil, roger federer.

item.title: factory explosion follows yemeni forces' pullout
item.description: yemen's political crisis deepened monday when an explosion tore through a crowd of looters at an abandoned government weapons factory in the south, killing at least 110 people.

item.title: oklahoma city airport partially shut to investigate package
item.description: authorities temporarily closed part of oklahoma city's will rogers world airport on friday to allow a police bomb squad to investigate a suspicious package.

item.title: southeast: pittsburgh 74, unc-asheville 51: no. 1 pittsburgh breezes through second round
item.description: ashton gibbs scored 20 of his 26 points after halftime, and pittsburgh kept the top seeds perfect against the 16s in the ncaa tournament.

item.title: heaven is a fairy tale, says physicist hawking
item.description: heaven is a fairy story for people afraid of the dark, the eminent british theoretical physicist stephen hawking said in an interview published on monday.

item.title: haiti's preval to u.n.: we need bulldozers, not tanks
item.description: it is time for the united nations to transform its mission in haiti, which needs engineers and bulldozers more than soldiers and tanks, outgoing haitian president rene preval said on wednesday.

item.title: "mad men" air date pushed back to early 2012
item.description: the ad agency drama "mad men," which was due to begin its fifth season in the summer, will not return until early 2012 because of stalled contract talks with its creator, cable channel amc said on tuesday.

item.title: observatory: in macaques, familiarity breeds...more macaques?
item.description: the monkeys seemed to notice a fertility signal in the females they knew, but not in ones they didn't, scientists find.
